entries: The mahoru has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the mahoru's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The mahoru has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that isn't at maximum hit points.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 3d10 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Roar
entries: When a mahoru roars all creatures with hearing within 30 feet of it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} until the end of the mahoru's next turn. If the target fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it's also {@condition paralyzed} for the same duration. A target that succeeds on the saving throw is immune to the Roar of all mahoru for the next 24 hours.

action.name: Vorpal Bite
entries: A mahoru's saw-like jaws excel at dismembering prey. When the mahoru scores a critical hit, the target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Strength saving throw or lose an appendage. Roll {@dice 1d12} on the following table for the result:
1–2: right hand
3–4: left hand
5–6: right foot
7–8: left foot
9: right forearm
10: left forearm
11: right lower leg
12: left lower leg

{@i I saw no more terrible beast on all my journeys north than the mahoru. The white bears had their aloof majesty, the lindwurm serpentine grace, but the monster that gnawed away the pack ice beneath our feet and savaged any who fell into the water was a thing of nightmare. The men it snatched were torn apart, like rags in the mouth of a rabid dog.}
A hybrid of fish and mammal, a mahoru is eight feet long and looks like a small orca with a serpentine neck and seal-like head.

entries.name: Valuable Teeth and Fur
entries: Their heavy jaws are filled with triangular, serrated teeth adept at tearing flesh and sundering bone. Their white and black fur is highly prized for its warmth and waterproof qualities. Their pectoral fins feature stubby, claw-tipped paws. Skraeling use the mahoru's fangs to make arrowheads or tooth-studded clubs, and the mahoru is a totem beast for many northern tribes.

entries.name: Iceberg Hunters
entries: Relatives of the bunyip, mahoru prowl northern coasts and estuaries, hunting among the fragmenting pack ice each summer. They lurk beneath the surface, catching swimmers chunks or lurching up onto the ice to break or tilt it and send prey tumbling into the water. When necessary, they stalk beaches and riverbanks in search of carrion or unwary victims.

entries.name: Work in Pairs and Packs
entries: Mahoru work together in mated pairs to corral everything from fish and seals to larger prey like kayaking humans and even polar bears. They gnaw at ice bridges and the frozen surface of lakes and rivers to create fragile patches that plunge unwary victims into their waiting jaws.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The lynx's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution. It can cast the following spell, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Smoky Constitution
entries: The vapor lynx spends its time in both gaseous and solid form. Its unique constitution makes it immune to all fog- or gas-related spells and attacks, including its own. A vapor lynx sees clearly through light or heavy obscurement caused by fog, mist, or spells such as {@spell fog cloud}.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The vapor lynx makes one bite attack and two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d8 + 4}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Poison Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The vapor lynx exhales a 40-foot radius poison fog, which heavily obscures a spherical area around the lynx. Any breathing creature that ends its turn in the fog must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} for {@dice 1d4 + 1} rounds.

{@i These great cats pad noiselessly, while tendrils of smoke drift off their sleek gray coats, leaving misty whorls in their wake. Their eyes shift from dull, pallid orbs to pitch black slits. Their lips curl up into a fang-revealing smile as their bodies fades into fog.}

entries.name: Split the Herd
entries: Vapor lynxes are capricious hunters. Devious, manipulative, and mischievous, they toy with their prey before killing it. They rarely enjoy a stand-up fight, instead coalescing in and out of the fog to harass victims. Using their ability to solidify and poison the fog around them, they cut large groups into smaller, more manageable morsels.

entries.name: Dreary Marshlands
entries: Their tactics have earned vapor lynxes a nasty reputation and the occasional bounty on their heads. Additionally, their magical nature makes them valuable to practitioners of the magical arts, and their beautiful, thick coats tempt many a furrier into hunts they may not be prepared for. For these reasons, vapor lynxes avoid civilization, fearing organized reprisal. Instead they haunt marshes and swamps, where the natural fog makes hunting easier. If an intelligent humanoid passes their way, they are happy for a change in their diet.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The great silverback makes one bite attack and two fist attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) bludgeoning damage. If the target is Medium or smaller, the great silverback can choose to grapple it.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 8} to hit, range 25/50 ft., one target. {@h}10 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Throw
entries: One Medium or smaller object or creature {@condition grappled} by the great silverback is thrown up to 15 feet in a random direction and knocked {@condition prone}. If a thrown target strikes a solid surface, the target takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage for every 5 feet it was thrown. If the target is thrown at another creature, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw or take the same damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Charging Bluff
entries: The great silverback moves at least 15 feet towards a target and then roars and beats its chest. The target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} until the end of its next turn.

action.name: Pummel {@recharge 5}
entries: The great silverback makes four fist attacks against a {@condition prone} target within 5 feet of it.

trait.name: Blood Frenzy
entries: The anophiloi has advantage on melee attack rolls against any creature that doesn't have all its hp.

trait.name: Blood Sense
entries: The anophiloi can pinpoint, by scent, the location of living creatures within 30 feet of it.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The anophiloi makes two attacks. one with its claws and one with its bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) piercing damage, and if the target is Large or smaller, the anophiloi attaches to it. While attached, the anophiloi doesn't attack. Instead, at the start of each of the anophiloi's turns, the target loses 5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) hp due to blood loss.

The anophiloi can detach itself by spending 5 feet of its movement. It does so after it drains 20 hit points of blood from the target or the target dies. A creature, including the target, can use its action to detach the anophiloi by succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength check.

action.name: Claws
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) slashing damage.
{@i With a needle-like snout and a gut full of blood, the anophiloi are hard to miss. The buzz of the creature's wings haunts the jungles and marshes, sending warm‑blooded creatures for cover.}

entries.name: Blood Drinkers
entries: Predators of the swamplands, jungles, and other humid places, the anophiloi, intelligent mosquitoes the size of large dogs, feed mainly on livestock and large game animals. Their choice of food, however, is a pragmatic one and has nothing to do with morality; game animals won't organize to wipe them out, humanoids will. When famished, anything that bleeds becomes prey for the anophiloi.

entries.name: Seasonal Menace
entries: The anophiloi require heat and humidity to thrive. They spend the cold months of the year dwindling in size and dehydrating while hidden in hibernation after one last gluttonous feeding. By the end of this dormant period, the creatures resemble a bundle of gray and black sticks. As soon as the temperature increases, the anophiloi take to the air and seek out easy prey.

entries.name: Barely Kept in Check
entries: The anophiloi's period of dormancy allows farmers and keepers of livestock to keep the creature's population thin. At the first dip in temperature, hunts are organized. If not for the frenetic pace and frequency of their egg laying, the anophiloi would be an unpleasant memory in settled regions.

trait.name: Arcane Discharge
entries: When an arcanaphage dies, it explodes in a surge of partially-digested magical energy. Each creature within 5 feet per Feed score must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 3 ({@damage 1d6}) force damage per Feed score on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. For 1 minute afterward, the affected area is awash with volatile magic. A creature that starts its turn in the affected area takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) force damage.

trait.name: Hunger
entries: Each time it feeds in combat, it regains hp equal to twice the level of the spell it ate and increases its Feed score by 1. The arcanaphage can't have a Feed score higher than 8, and its Feed score reduces by 1 each time it finishes a long rest.

trait.name: Ingest Magic
entries: At the start of each of the arcanaphage's turns, each creature within 30 feet of it that is currently maintaining concentration on a spell must make a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature's spell ends and the arcanaphage feeds.

trait.name: Magic Immunity
entries: The arcanaphage is immune to damage from spells. It has advantage on saving throws against all other magical effects.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: The arcanaphage can breathe air and water.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The arcanaphage makes two tentacle attacks.

action.name: Tentacle
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 3}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Arcane Beam
entries: The arcanaphage fires a powerful beam of arcane energy at one creature within 60 feet of it that it can see. The arcanaphage expends its stored magic, depleting its Feed score by 1. On a hit, the target takes 4 ({@damage 1d6}) force damage. The arcanaphage can expend an additional Feed point to increase this damage by 4 ({@damage 1d6}), to a maximum of 7 points.

If the arcanaphage expends up to 4 Feed points in a single turn, the target must roll on the Wild Magic table, treating itself as the target. If the arcanaphage expends up to 8 Feed points in a single turn, the arcanaphage can choose what magical effect the creature is afflicted with.

action.name: Devour Arcana {@recharge 5}
entries: The arcanaphage's outstretched tentacles glow a sudden and bright pink as it feeds on the arcane. The arcanaphage chooses one creature, object, or magical effect within 30 feet of it, devouring the effect. This action works like the dispel magic spell, except the arcanaphage must always make a spellcasting ability check, no matter the spell level. Its ability check for this is +6. If it successfully dispels the spell, the arcanaphage feeds.

reaction.name: Voracious
entries: The arcanaphage's tentacles glow when a spell is cast within 30 feet of it, countering the spell. This reaction works like the counterspell spell, except the arcanaphage must always make a spellcasting ability check, no matter the spell level. Its ability check for this is +6. If it successfully counters the spell, the arcanaphage feeds.
{@i A soft-bodied, iridescent creature floats by, tentacles rippling along its back as it quests for its next meal.}
Arcanaphage are commonly found in places imbued with magic, their colorful skin rhythmically pulsating as they graze on arcane energies.

entries.name: Magivore
entries: The arcanaphage's  diet consists almost exclusively of magic, though it consumes on zooplankton as well. This sea slug has no mouth; it feeds by absorbing nearby magical energy into a series of ropy tentacles that run the length of its body. With enough time, an arcanaphage can slowly slurp all of the power out of magical objects, traps, or spells permanently imbuing an area. Most arcanaphage are about the size of a large dog, though especially well-fed specimens the size of draft horses have been reported.

entries.name: Docile Unless Angered
entries: If left to feed undisturbed, an arcanaphage typically ignores its surroundings. However, when it feels threatened or when food is scarce and it senses magic nearby, it viciously attacks.

entries.name: Unwitting Guardians
entries: Its ability to neutralize magic in its immediate area, combined with its calm demeanor, makes an arcanaphage an excellent guardian against a wizard's ire. Some warlords even bring pet arcanaphage to battle as protection from spellcasters, although this is a gamble since the creatures like to sit on and absorb power from unattended magical objects, like a warlord's heirloom weapon, and can release a torrent of magical energy when slain.

trait.name: Expansive
entries: A creature at least one size smaller than the goliath longlegs can travel through and finish its turn in the goliath longlegs' space.

trait.name: False Appearance
entries: While a goliath longlegs remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from other plants or trees.

trait.name: Forest Camouflage
entries: The goliath longlegs has advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks made to hide in forested terrain.

trait.name: Vulnerable Legs
entries: The goliath longlegs has eight legs. While it has more than four legs, the goliath longlegs is immune to being knocked {@condition prone} or {@condition restrained}. Whenever the goliath longlegs takes 20 or more damage in a single turn, one of its legs is destroyed. Each time a leg is destroyed after the fourth one, the goliath longlegs must succeed on a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw or fall {@condition prone}. Any creature in the goliath longlegs' space or within 5 feet of it when it falls {@condition prone} must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking 21 ({@damage 6d6}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The goliath longlegs makes one bite attack and then as many leg attacks as it has legs. It can use its Reel in place of two leg attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}8 ({@damage 1d8 + 7}) piercing damage and the target must make a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw, taking 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If the poison damage reduces the target to 0 hp, the target is stable but {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour, even after regaining hp, and is {@condition paralyzed} while {@condition poisoned} in this way.

action.name: Leg
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 1d10 + 7}) piercing damage.

action.name: Paralytic Web {@recharge 5}
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 30/60 ft., one Large or smaller creature. {@h}The creature is {@condition restrained} by webbing and must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the {@condition paralyzed} effect on itself on a success. As an action, the {@condition restrained} creature can make a {@dc 18} Strength check, escaping from the webbing on a success. The webbing can also be attacked and destroyed (AC 14; hp 30; vulnerability to fire damage; immunity to bludgeoning, poison, and psychic damage).

action.name: Reel
entries: The goliath longlegs pulls one creature caught in its web up to 30 feet straight toward it. If the target is within 10 feet of the goliath longlegs, the goliath longlegs can make one bite attack as a bonus action.
{@i A spider the size of a large house, with legs that could pass for trees, moves through the forest.}
Solitary hunters, goliath longlegs sit motionless for long periods of time, waiting for unsuspecting prey to walk beneath them.

entries.name: Stealthy Ambush Predators
entries: The legs of a goliath longlegs mimic the size and texture of the trees of the forest in which it resides. It uses this natural camouflage to its advantage, hiding its body in the crowns of the nearby trees.

entries.name: Venomous Weapons
entries: The goliath longlegs' legs are vulnerable to attack, so it prefers to poison its prey with a paralyzing nerve agent.

entries.name: Unknown Origin
entries: Not much is known about the origin of this species. They are few in number, and, when one is discovered, word rarely gets back to civilization.

trait.name: Radioactive Aura
entries: At the start of each of the radiant carnotaurus' turns, each creature within 20 feet of it must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

trait.name: Trampling Charge
entries: If the radiant carnotaurus moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a gore attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the radiant carnotaurus can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The radiant carnotaurus makes one gore attack and one bite attack.

action.name: Gore
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}19 ({@damage 4d6 + 6}) piercing damage.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 3d10 + 6}) piercing damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or become infected with the corpse cough disease (see the Corpse Cough trait).

action.name: Irradiated Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The radiant carnotaurus' exhales radioactive fire in a 30-foot cone, bathing it in blazing purple flame. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 35 ({@damage 10d6}) radiant damage and is infected with the corpse cough disease (see the Corpse Cough trait). On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't infected with the disease.

variant.name: Corpse Cough
entries: Those who fail a saving throw against the radiant carnotaurus' Irradiated Breath or Bite attack become infected with the corpse cough disease. The infected creature can't benefit from short or long rests due to a constant, wet cough. The infected creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw each day or take 18 ({@damage 4d8}) radiant damage. The target's hit point maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the radiant damage taken. The target dies if this effect reduces its hit point maximum to 0. Additionally, the infected creature has disadvantage on Strength and Constitution saving throws, attack rolls, and skill checks. These reductions lasts until the target is cured of the disease with a {@spell greater restoration} spell or similar magic. If the infected creature comes into physical contact with another living creature or is within 10 feet of one before the disease is cured, the uninfected creature must succeed on a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw or also become infected with the disease. The newly-infected is afflicted with a constant, wet cough within hours of infection, but the disease's full effects don't manifest until {@dice 1d4} days later. Corpse cough is so named due to the smell of the cough as the infected creature's lungs become necrotic.
{@i This muscular archosaur has a pair of wide horns, like those of a bull, and a reddish tint in its eyes that emits a sickening radiance.}

{@b Irradiated Predator.} Known to be a bringer of incredible sickness, radiant carnotauruses are sought after for their horns and their teeth, both believed to have powerful curative properties. The bones of a radiant carnotaurus are highly radioactive and can prove fatal to any creature that strays too close to it.

{@b Wilderness Wanderer.} Radiant carnotaureses travel across entire continents, never staying in one area for more than a few seasons. They are swift and powerful hunters that use their overwhelming bulk to knock prey to the ground and rip them to pieces.

{@b Grisly Signs.} Travelers should take warning when approaching the mutilated remains of an animal in an isolated area. Anything killed by a radiant carnotaurus becomes a beacon of radiation, and can irradiate other creatures that draw too close.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The scitalis has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage plus 9 ({@damage 2d8}) poison damage.

action.name: Stunning Scales
entries: Each creature of the scitalis' choice that is within 60 feet of the scitalis and can see it must succeed on a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition stunned} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the scitalis' Stunning Scales for the next 24 hours.

{@i The skin of this large snake is covered in an elegant pattern of intricate markings that scintillate with an eerie, supernatural brilliance. Its scales undulate a mesmerizing glamour as it slowly slithers forward.}

entries.name: Hypnotic Serpents
entries: The scitalis is a deadly serpentine monstrosity that stuns its prey with the marvelous glimmer of its magically-variegated skin. Unlike most ophidians, these venomous hunters move rather slowly and rely on the stupefying effects of their otherworldly scales to capture the fleet of foot. With its prey adequately disabled, the scitalis languidly closes in to feast.

entries.name: Warm-bodied Wyrms
entries: Due to the strange quality of its iridescent skin, the scitalis is actually a warm-blooded reptile. This torpid supernatural monstrosity is cold-resistant and can be seen wandering as far as the frigid climes of the arctic. The snakeskin of the scitalis maintains some of its enchanted properties once shed and can often fetch handsome rewards from purveyors of the arcane.

entries.name: Eldritch Origins
entries: The provenance of the scitalis is a mystery as stupefying as its gleaming scales. Some sages speculate a draconic pedigree, while others claim this beautiful but deadly ophidian is a true child of Yig, the blasphemous Father of Serpents. Scitalis sightings are infrequent enough to fuel speculative and disquieting reports of variant breeds—glittering serpents with sinister spines, bat-like wings, or several sharp-toothed heads.
This creature's hide is required component for the {@item Cloak of Iridescence|CCodex}

trait.name: Hypnotic Plumage
entries: When a creature that can see the sunset raptor's tail starts its turn within 100 feet of the raptor, the raptor can force it to make a {@dc 14} Wisdom saving throw if the raptor isn't {@condition incapacitated} and can see the creature. On a failure, a creature becomes {@condition charmed} until the start of its next turn. While {@condition charmed}, the creature is {@condition incapacitated} as it suffers from surreal hallucinations and must move up to its speed closer to the raptor that {@condition charmed} it. It doesn't avoid opportunity attacks, but before moving into damaging terrain, such as lava or a pit, and whenever it takes damage from a source other than the sunset raptor, a target can repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on itself on a success. Other sunset raptors are immune to this effect.

Unless surprised, a creature can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the creature does so, it can't see the sunset raptor until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If the creature looks at the sunset raptor in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The sunset raptor has advantage on attack rolls against a creature if at least one of the raptor's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the sunset raptor moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 13} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the sunset raptor can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The sunset raptor makes two attacks. one with its bite and one with its claw.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 2d6 + 3}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) slashing damage
The captain just stared with wet eyes and a dazed smile, whispering something I couldn't hear. He just stared while they tore him apart. I just stared while they tore him apart.
entries.by: The lone survivor of a sunset raptor attack

entries.name: Beautiful Threat
entries: The sunset raptor can be identified by its crimson plumage, crested head, and large peacock-like tail of golden feathers. Its tail feathers are reflective and mesmerizing, triggering surreal hallucinations of a spectator's dreams, desires, and nightmares.

entries.name: Deadly Oddities
entries: Vicious and exotic, sunset raptors are highly prized among eccentric collectors. They can often be found guarding the lairs of mad wizards or stalking the gardens of giants. Jewelers, alchemists, and fortune tellers covet sunset raptor feathers for their bright color and use in spiritual rituals. However, sunset raptors are not easily caught or tamed, and many hunters and handlers have been devoured for not taking the proper precautions against these vibrant killers.

entries.name: Social Predators
entries: Sunset raptors have developed remarkably efficient pack tactics. They communicate using shrill, piercing calls, sacrificing the element of surprise in favor of swiftly coordinated attacks. Often, the fastest raptors run ahead of the pack, cutting off potential prey. Once their prey is cornered, the raptors close in, forming a ring and forcing their prey to gaze upon their deadly, hypnotic plumag.

trait.name: Reactive Heads
entries: The three-headed cobra gets two extra reactions that can be used only for opportunity attacks.

trait.name: Three-headed
entries: The cobra has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Wakeful
entries: While the three-headed cobra sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The three-headed cobra makes three bite attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d6 + 4}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) poison damage. Additionally, the bitten creature must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition poisoned} and take {@damage 1d6} Constitution damage. A {@condition poisoned} creature repeats the saving throw every four hours, taking another {@damage 1d6} Constitution damage for each failure, until it has made two consecutive successful saves or survived for 24 hours. The creature dies if its Constitution score reaches 0. If the creature survives, the effect ends and the creature can heal normally. Lost Constitution can be regained with a lesser restoration spell or comparable magic.

{@i This monstrous serpent's body is as thick as a man's torso and covered in ink-black scales. Its trunk branches out to support three hissing heads atop flaring cobra hoods. For all its size, it slithers across the ground almost silently.}
Often employed as guardians, the native intelligence of these creatures makes them capable of learning commands.

entries.name: Color Variations
entries: The three-headed cobra is most common throughout warm climates, though not unknown on the open plains and in some jungles. While most retain the black coloration found in jungles and hills, other varieties exist. The desert variety often has a pale bone color and skull-like hood pattern; the plains varieties tend toward green or khaki coloration.

entries.name: Golden Guardians
entries: The three-headed cobra is a watchful creature associated with guarding shrines and sometimes with rulership over a particular abandoned city or necropolis. Some believe they are protectors of ancient holy relics, sacred scrolls, or divine sparks. Because one of its heads is always awake and alert, it is also favored to guard treasure vaults and counting houses, where large sums of coins are stored. In these cases, the three-headed cobra's scales take on a golden or silvery coloration.

entries.name: Servants of the Queen
entries: The three-headed cobra carries a strong association with the Queen of Serpents, who, according to legend, never strays far from their protection (honor guards of at least two and as many as a dozen are common near the Queen). They are thought to be her close companions, and many believe the three-headed cobras serve not only as her bodyguards but also as her consorts.

trait.name: Flyby
entries: The two-headed eagle doesn't provoke an opportunity attack when it flies out of an enemy's reach.

trait.name: Two-headed
entries: The eagle has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}.

trait.name: Wakeful
entries: While the two-headed eagle sleeps, at least one of its heads is awake.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The two-headed eagle makes two bite attacks and one talons attack.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}12 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) piercing damage and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 16}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the two-headed eagle can't use its talons on another target.

{@i With two sets of sharp eyes and razor-sharp beaks, the two-headed eagle spots its prey and snatches it up with frightening speed. Drawn to shiny objects, the eagle swoops down, snatching a mounted knight from its horse.}

{@b Hunters of the Unseen.} Enormous birds of prey, twoheaded eagles soar the skies of many parts of the world, using their extraordinarily keen vision to hunt down prey and threats to their nests alike. Their ability to see invisible creatures has led to many ill-fated attempts to raid their nests; the same ability that makes them so sought after as potential guardians also makes their nests nigh impossible to approach undetected.

{@b Dangerous Favorites.} Considered to be wise birds, they are nonetheless attracted to shiny objects, much to the dismay of the occasional, armored noble. This tendency, coupled with their disdain for herds of livestock as prey, has played a large role in their continued favor among villagers and country folk in many lands. While two-headed eagles do feed on deer, elk, and other game favored by hunters, their preferred prey consists of giant snakes, wild and dire boar, and large river fish.

{@b Symbol of the Watchful.} Known for their ability to see the invisible, two-headed eagles appear frequently on coats of arms, symbolizing watchfulness, a dedication to truth, or a wariness for deception or assassins.

monster.name: The Gargoyle

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (1/Day)
entries: If the Gargoyle fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Towering Strength
entries: The Gargoyle can lift up to 80,000 pounds.

trait.name: Ember Wreath (1/Day)
entries: As a bonus action, the Gargoyle wreathes its body in searing red and orange embers. The embers last for 1 minute or until the ape uses its breath weapon. A creature that enters or starts its turn in a space within 30 feet of the ape must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. If a creature fails the saving throw by 5 or more, it suffers one level of {@condition exhaustion} as the water is sapped from its body by the unrelenting heat.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Gargoyle makes a bite attack and two fist attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 2d10 + 7}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Fist
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 3d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage and the target must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Comet
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 11} to hit, range 50/100 ft., one target. {@h}21 ({@damage 4d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage.

action.name: Immolating Breath {@recharge 5}
entries: The Gargoyle exhales intense flame in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Dexterity saving throw, taking 63 ({@damage 18d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

legendaryHeader: The Gargoyle can take 3 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action option can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The ape regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

legendary.name: Tail Attack
entries: The Gargoyle makes a tail attack.

legendary.name: Grab
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 11} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 19}) and {@condition restrained}.

legendary.name: Throw
entries: The Gargoyle throws one creature it has {@condition grappled}. The creature is thrown a distance of {@dice 2d6} times 10 feet in the direction the ape chooses, and takes 20 ({@damage 2d12 + 7}) bludgeoning damage (plus falling damage if they are thrown into a chasm or off a cliff). The ape can throw a creature up to Large size. Small creatures are thrown twice as far, but the damage is the same.

legendary.name: Wing Attack (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: The Gargoyle beats its wings. Each creature within 15 ft. of the ape must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw or take 16 ({@damage 2d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage plus 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. The Gargoyle can then fly up to half its flying speed.

{@italic As the surrounding blizzard persisted mercilessly, two young goliaths trekked through the rock and snow. As stubborn as they were, they were unwilling to admit that they were lost, miles away from their mountainous village. As the pair stopped for a brief rest, a deep, grumbling roar pierced the shrieking winds. To their horror, the silhouette of an ogre loomed just meters away from them, wielding a colossal tree trunk. Exhausted and sore, the two goliaths gripped their weapons tightly, readying themselves for their final battle. As the ogre charged, the two goliaths let out a triumphant war cry which, to their surprise, was overtaken by an echoing draconic roar that carried for miles. From behind, the two goliaths felt an intense heat grace their backs, melting the frost and snow. They watched as a massive, winged figure leapt high above their heads before crashing atop the bewildered ogre. The ape-like creature subjected the troll-kin to a flurry of devastating blows, shattering its bones like paper. With a ferocious, bellowing roar, the ogre was lifted high above the beast’s head and effortlessly thrown to the jagged rocks below. Both impressed and terrified, the two goliaths looked on in awe as the creature turned to them and bowed its head before unfurling its massive wings and taking flight, vanishing from sight in a swarm of embers.}
A legendary creature of both draconic and simian descent, the Gargoyle is a savior to those lost in the desolate, frozen mountains that it calls home.

{@bold Mysterious Origins.} The circumstances in which the Gargoyle was born is considered a mystery by all, as its unique combination of both draconic and hominid traits is, as far as most are concerned, completely irreproducible. It is heavily speculated that the creature is a half-dragon of sorts, but the manner in which it was conceived is unknown. Nonetheless, the Gargoyle combines the traits of a silverback gorilla and a red dragon to devastating effect. Covered in both the muscular, impenetrable hide of a dragon and the shaggy, warming fur of an ape, the Gargoyle is, for an unknown reason, mostly gray, resembling a stone statue. The only touch of color present on the massive creature is its massive, leathery wings, in which its membrane is a darkened crimson. The Gargoyle earned its name due to these wings, its bestial humanoid physique, the concrete-like appearance of its hide, and its long, dragon-like tail that ends in a devilish point.

{@bold Chimeric Personality.} Similarly to its appearance, the Gargoyle’s personality is tainted by draconic habit. The beast shares a fondness of mountains with its reptilian parent, preferring to lair at high altitudes. It shares a dragon’s greed, collecting trinkets and other items that it considers to be valuable, which are often playthings. It collects wagon wheels, tree trunks, boulders, and even other animals. It’s extremely fond of large grazing animals such as yaks and elk. The Gargoyle is omnivorous, although it prefers to live a more herbivorous lifestyle, grazing with its “troop” and protecting them ferociously. While normally docile and playful, if the Gargoyle encounters anything it perceives as a threat to itself or its troop, it will attack with unexpected levels of primal aggression, combining the blazing fury of a red dragon and the frightening strength of a gorilla. Its mastery of flame surpasses its parent’s, allowing it to wreathe itself in scorching embers.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The Paka Paka's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom. It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Pounce
entries: If the Paka Paka moves at least 20 feet straight toward a creature and then hits it with a claw attack on the same turn, that target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the Paka Paka can make one bite attack against it as a bonus action.

trait.name: Keen Sight and Smell
entries: The Paka Paka has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or smell.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Paka Paka makes two claw attacks.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d10 + 5}) piercing damage. If the target is {@condition prone}, this attack scores a critical hit.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 2d6 + 5}) slashing damage. If the Paka Paka hits the same target with two claw attacks on the same turn, the target is also {@condition grappled}.

action.name: Blink {@recharge 4}
entries: The Paka Paka magically teleports, along with any equipment it is wearing or carrying, up to 90 feet to an unoccupied space it can see. Before or after teleporting, the Paka Paka can make one claw attack. The Paka Paka can bring any creature it is grappling with it.

bonus.name: Feline Agility
entries: The Paka Paka can take the Dash or Disengage action.

reaction.name: Ferocious Bite
entries: If a creature is {@condition grappled} by the Paka Paka at the end of the creature's turn, the Paka Paka makes a bite attack against it with advantage.

{@italic Slinking through the darkness of the Sloefire, a cat-like creature stalks its prey. Its skeletal front-limbs and skull reflect the pale moonlight as it pokes its head out from the dark, zeroing in on a lone deer. With a flash, purple flames erupt from its back, and the feline is gone, suddenly reappearing on the deer’s back.}
The Paka Paka is a legendary creature native to the Sloefire bog that uses an innate magical connection to teleport freely.

{@bold Blinking Predator.} This big cat is thought to have been one of the several species of feline that used to reside within the Sloefire bog before the Calamity. Afterwards, arcane radiation began to tamper with one individual cat, causing it to change exponentially. The Paka Paka has skeletal forelimbs and an animated skull, with piercing purple eyes within its sockets. A ghastly flame burns at the tip of its tail like the tuft of hair at the end of lion’s. Ages later, the Paka Paka persists, hunting with methods unlike any other animal. The Paka Paka has an extraordinary talent that allows it to “blink” effortlessly, similar to the blink dogs of the Feywild.  The Paka Paka can temporarily phase in and out of existence to some extent, giving the illusion of blinking between location to location. When blinking, ghostly purple flames erupt from its neck and back like the mane of a horse, sending violet embers scattering through the air. Unlike blink dogs, the Paka Paka can teleport while blinking, allowing it to clear expansive terrain in seconds.

{@bold Ethereal Wanderer.} The Paka Paka has a connection to the Ethereal Plane unique only to this animal. Its extraordinarily keen vision allows it to peer into the Ethereal Plane to see the unseen, making it impossible to escape. When resting, the Paka Paka will often reside in the Ethereal Plane to avoid potential predators, though this Ethereal connection is not absolute. As a result, the Paka Paka may appear to “flicker” in and out of existence every few seconds, giving off a disorienting appearance.

{@bold Legendary Beast.} With its skeletal features and predatory prowess, the Paka Paka quickly became a creature of interest to the remaining sentient inhabitants of the Sloefire bog, most prominently the lizardfolk tribe. Its likeness can be seen in murals, paintings, and art produced by them, and it is revered by many. As a result, its legendary status is rewarded with offerings of riches, delicacies, and totems. An individual who has seen the Paka Paka is regarded as extremely fortunate.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Violothéos fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: Violothéos has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Primal Strikes
entries: Violothéos' attacks are considered magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: Violothéos deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Trample
entries: When Violothéos enters a creature's space for the first time on a turn, the creature must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

trait.name: Amphibious
entries: Violothéos can breathe air and water.

trait.name: Atomic Absorption
entries: Whenever Violothéos is subjected to radiant damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the damage dealt. Additionally, Violothéos' breath weapon immediately recharges.

trait.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: If Violothéos fails a saving throw, it can choose to succeed instead.

trait.name: Atomic Force
entries: Violothéos is an overwhelming force of atomic annihilation. Each creature that starts its turn within 30 feet of Violothéos is subjected to the sickening radiance spell (save {@dc 21}). Additionally, the growth of plants and other flora is provoked into hyperactivity due to the radiation, causing areas affected by Violothéos' destruction to be  entirely overtaken by various flora in {@damage 1d4 x 10} days.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: Violothéos makes four attacks: one with its bite, two with its claws, and one with its tail. It can't make a tail attack against the same target it hits with a bite attack. It can make a Swallow attack in place of a bite.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}33 ({@damage 5d12 + 9}) piercing damage and an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage. If the target is a creature, it is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 21}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and Violothéos can't bite another target.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 4d6 + 9}) slashing damage and an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 20 ft., one target. {@h}20 ({@damage 4d8 + 9}) bludgeoning damage and an additional 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 21} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}.

action.name: Swallow
entries: Violothéos makes one bite attack against a Large or smaller creature it is grappling. If the attack hits, that creature takes the bite's damage and is swallowed, and the grapple ends. While swallowed, the creature is {@condition blinded} and {@condition restrained}, it has total cover against attacks and other effects outside of Violothéos , and it takes 21 ({@damage 6d6}) acid damage and 7 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage at the start of each of Violothéos' turns.

If Violothéos takes 30 damage or more on a single turn from a creature inside it, it must succeed on a {@dc 18} Constitution saving throw at the end of that turn or regurgitate all swallowed creatures, which fall {@condition prone} in a space within 10 feet of it. If Violothéos dies, a swallowed creature is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and can escape from the corpse by using 20 feet of movement, exiting {@condition prone}.

action.name: Breath Weapon {@recharge 5}
entries: Violothéos uses one of the following breath weapons.

{@bold Atomic Breath.} Violothéos exhales atomic energy in a line that is 90 feet long and 10 feet wide. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 21} Dexterity saving throw, taking 55 ({@damage 10d10}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

{@bold Nuclear Burst.} Violothéos becomes super-heated with atomic energy, expelling a devastating nuclear blast outwards in a 40-foot radius blast around it. Each creature caught in the blast must succeed on a {@dc 22} Constitution saving throw or take 22 (6d10) radiant and thunder damage, be pushed up to 30 feet away from Violothéos, and be knocked {@condition prone}. On a success, a creature takes half the radiant and thunder damage and isn't pushed or knocked {@condition prone}. A creature is {@condition poisoned} for 1 hour as a result of the blast. While {@condition poisoned} this way, the target's movement speed is halved and it has disadvantage on Strength checks or saving throws. Additionally, the creature only deals half damage with a melee weapon attack or an unarmed strike. The creature can repeat the initial Constitution save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

action.name: Shockwave
entries: Violothéos rears up and comes crashing down to earth. All creatures and structures on the ground within 100 feet of Violothéos (other than itself) are affected as they would be by the {@spell earthquake} spell (save {@dc 21}).

legendary.name: Rush
entries: Violothéos moves up to its speed.

legendary.name: Attack
entries: Violothéos makes a tail or claw attack.

legendary.name: Roar (Costs 2 Actions)
entries: Each creature that is within 120 feet of Violothéos and can hear it must succeed on a {@dc 21} Wisdom saving throw or become {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to Violothéos' Roar for the next 24 hours.

{@italic Stirring from its century-long slumber, a creature of titanic proportions surfaces from deep within the ocean. Lesser beings flee in its wake, careful not to be crushed underfoot by the massive beast as it makes landfall. Its sheer presence ionizes the surrounding environment, causing strange mutations in organisms after prolonged exposure. The titan lets out a grumbling roar that echoes for miles. Violothéos has awakened.}

{@bold Radioactive Titan.} Closely related to a smaller genus of innately radioactive spinosaurids, Violothéos has grown to a massive size through unknown means. Some claim that the beast is a close relative of the tarrasque, but given its close ties to a separate, smaller species, it may be safe to assume that this is not the case. It is widely believed that the beast was mutated by overexposure to arcane radiation, which it exerts a peculiar mastery over. Violothéos’ signature weapon is its “atomic breath,” nuclear energy that it generates inside of its body, harnessing electromagnetic force to concentrate it into a laser-like high velocity projectile. The energy is released in the form of a pink radioactive beam, which is capable of melting and vaporizing anything it comes into contact with. Through a similar method, Violothéos can exhale a wave of lethal radiation, irradiating anything it passes through. It is capable of both bipedal and quadrupedal locomotion, although it primarily moves quadrupedally whilst moving terrestrially. Two tusks at the tip of its jaw allow it to grasp and pierce more effectively, along with its peculiar ability to unhinge its jaw similar to a snake. The lizard is naturally immune to extreme heat, cold, radiation, and most forms of conventional weaponry, making it a true force of ultimate calamity.

{@bold Indifferent Guardian.} While Violothéos clearly possesses the ability to lay waste to most life on the continents, it instead chooses to remain sealed away in the darkest crevasses of the sea, slumbering in wait for a global threat to arise. When the planet is faced with global annihilation, the Violothéos will awaken, using its atomic might to topple any foe. When active, Violothéos will remain indifferent to and oftentimes completely ignore all smaller life, regarding them as a warrior would a mere ant. This can prove to be destructive at times, causing Violothéos to lay waste to villages and cities along its journey.

{@bold Misunderstood Defender.} Oftentimes, a powerful city or hold will use magic to retaliate against Violothéos. While the massive reptile is naturally resistant to the arcane, it is not immune. If sufficiently damaged, Violothéos will defend itself, targeting the attackers and casting them into oblivion with its atomic fury. This usually leads to further destruction, which causes many to resent Violothéos, assuming it to be a malevolent force. This could not be further from the truth, and thus Violothéos lives a very conflicted life, attacked by the very creatures it attempts to defend.

{@b (DISCLAIMER: THIS CREATURE'S CHALLENGE RATING IS NOT ACCURATE. SEVERAL TEMPLATES HAVE BEEN APPLIED TO THE BASE CREATURE (Young Spinosaurus) ALONG WITH A FEW FLUFF ABILITIES, MAKING THIS CREATURE ROUGHLY CR 11 AFTER ALL TEMPLATES HAVE BEEN APPLIED. IN REALITY, THIS CREATURE IS ABOUT CR 24. USE CAUTIOUSLY WHEN BALANCING FOR AN ENCOUNTER.)}

trait.name: Acid Burn
entries: If a creature wearing armor or wielding a weapon takes acid damage from one of the loxorosa's attacks, that creature must succeed on a {@dc 19} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the loxorosa decides which one of the following effects happen:

{@bold Armor.} The armor it is wearing takes a cumulative -1 penalty to its AC. Nonmagical armor reduced to an AC of 10 is destroyed. Magical armor reduced to an AC of 10 no longer gains the benefits of any of its magical properties for one week, but its AC returns to normal after a long rest.

{@bold Weapon.} The weapon takes a cumulative -1 penalty to its attack and damage rolls. A nonmagical weapon reduced to -5 in its attack and damage rolls is destroyed. A magical weapon reduced to -5 no longer gains the benefits of any of its properties for one week, but it becomes a mundane weapon after a long rest.
{@bold Corrosion} The target takes 10 ({@damage 4d4}) acid damage at the beginning of its next turn.

trait.name: Sharpened Tusks
entries: The loxorosa can use its bonus action to to sharpen its tusks, removing the acidic moss that covers it; or it can use a bonus action to regrow it.

trait.name: Swamp Camouflage
entries: The loxrosa has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in swampy terrain.

trait.name: Trunk
entries: The loxorosa has a long, muscular trunk that can grasp objects and be used as a snorkel. It has a reach of 15 feet, and it can lift up to 700 pounds.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The loxorosa deals double damage to objects and structures.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The loxorosa makes two tusk attacks. If both attacks hit the same target, the target must succeed on a {@dc 18} Strength or Dexterity saving throw (target's choice) or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition prone}, the loxorosa can make one stomp attack against it as a bonus action.

action.name: Tusk
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}22 ({@damage 3d8 + 6}) piercing damage plus 7 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage when covered in acidic moss. If sharpened, the target takes 39 ({@damage 6d8 + 6}) piercing damage instead.

action.name: Stomp
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}25 ({@damage 3d12 + 6}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Goring Rush
entries: The loxorosa uses one of the following goring rush attacks depending on which form its tusks are in. Both share the same recharge.

{@bold Acidic Rush (Recharge 5–6).} The loxorosa launches itself forward 40 feet without provoking opportunity attacks, using its tusks to gore all foes within a 10-foot radius of its path. Each creature in that area must then make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 24 ({@dice 7d6}) slashing and 24 ({@damage 7d6}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

{@bold Sharpened Rush (Recharge 5–6).} The loxorosa launches itself forward 40 feet without provoking opportunity attacks, using its tusks to gore all foes within a 10-foot radius of its path. Each creature in that area must then make a {@dc 18} Dexterity saving throw, taking 63 ({@damage 18d6}) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

{@italic Wading through the murky, ink-like water, a massive mammoth lumbers through a dense swamp. Crocodiles surface in order to give it a wide berth, careful not to be crushed underneath this colossal beast. Acidic moss, fungi, and other various plant matter is intertwined with its fur, making it appear green and plant-like.}
The loxorosa is a massive swamp-dwelling proboscid that has formed a symbiotic relationship with the various forms of plant life that grows in its fur.

{@bold Lumbering Giants.} Like elephants and mammoths, the loxorosa is a lumbering titan that is capable of breaking into a thunderous charge, but it prefers to move slowly and calmly unless provoked. Slightly more aggressive than elephants but slower to anger than mammoths, loxorosas are often calm, level-headed animals who are content with eating aquatic vegetation all day. Unlike most proboscids, the loxorosa is mostly solitary, occasionally forming groups of two to three individuals who travel and play with one another like elephants would.

{@bold Vegetal Symbiosis.} The environment the loxorosa inhabit have led to an evolutionary pairing between the loxorosa and various species of plant matter. The plant matter grows within the loxorosa’s shaggy fur, entangling itself to get a better grip. In exchange for frequent time in the sun along with watering and rich fertilizer, the plant matter excretes an extremely powerful acidic compound that can melt most materials with ease, targeting them at the cellular level. The only exception to this corrosive property is anything carrying the loxorosa’s genetic material, which is practically immune to most forms of corrosion. Loxorosas cover their tusks with mold and vines in order to inflict a corrosive strike to anything that dares cross it.

trait.name: Keen Hearing and Smell
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the wolf's allies is within 5 ft. of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Ice Walk
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf can move across and climb icy surfaces without needing to make an ability check. Additionally, difficult terrain composed of ice or snow doesn't cost it extra movement.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf makes two bite attacks. If both attacks hit the target and the target is a creature, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 15}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) piercing damage. If the target is a creature, it must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. If the target is {@condition frightened} it takes an additional 22 ({@damage 2d10}) cold damage. This attack ignores damage resistance.

action.name: Call the Pack (Recharges on a Long Rest)
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf magically duplicates itself, creating up to five spiritual replicas at a point it can see within 60 feet of itself. Each replica uses the statistics of the Fang of the Great Wolf except it does not have access to the Call the Pack trait. The Great Wolf can communicate telepathically with a replica as long as they are within 120 feet of each other. The replicas act as allies of the Great Wolf and obey its telepathic commands. The replicas remain until killed or dismissed by the Great Wolf as a bonus action. Slain or dismissed replicas vaporize into glowing blue wisps of rime.

action.name: Howling Winds {@recharge 5}
entries: The Fang of the Great Wolf emits a keening howl of freezing wind in a 60-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 17} Constitution saving throw, taking 18 ({@damage 4d8}) cold damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. In addition, each creature in that area that isn't {@condition deafened} must succeed on a {@dc 17} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of the Great Wolf until the end of the wolf's next turn. While a creature is {@condition frightened} in this way, its speed is halved, and it is {@condition incapacitated}.

variant.name: Maw of the Great Hyena
entries: While most individuals only view hyenas as the tainted offspring of Yeenoghu, they are still wild beasts, and aspects of nature still take hold of them on occasion. Roaming the savannas and deserts is a fierce hyena the size of a horse, cackling and snarling amidst the intense heat that radiates off of it. The Maw of the Great Hyena's abilities are almost identical to the Fang of the Great Wolf's, although their cold-oriented abilities and immunities are replaced with fire.

{@italic As a lone bull moose crosses an icy chasm, crossing a bridge of ice and darkened, wet stone. A group of blue glowing runes and various patterns stand out from the mist and snow just ahead of it. The moose stops, eying the lights mysteriously. Two parallel lights seem to open, transfixed on the moose for a moment before a howl as frigid and piercing as an arctic blizzard pervaded the ambient silence. Two more pairs of runes and eyes suddenly appear besides the mysterious figure before rushing towards the moose, revealing themselves to be pale wolves covered in glowing patterns and symbols. The moose turns to flee before finding that three more glowing wolves have cut off its exit. Turning to defend itself, a wolf latches down onto its knee, forcing it to the ground as the rest of the wolves pounced upon it, ripping into it without mercy. }

In the frigid tundra of Faerûn, near the Icewind Dale, legends of a white wolf covered in glowing runes, symbols, and patterns pass through the crews of ships and the patrons of local taverns like wildlife. They say it hides within the tundra, its pale, frosted fur allowing it to hide amongst the dark and snow. They also mention that one to seems to turn into two, and two into six. These claims are often dismissed, but most would be keen to listen to these survivors for their own safety. The Great Wolf is out there, and the Fang hungers.

{@bold Self-Made Pack.} The Fang of the Great Wolf is a pure white dire wolf, save for several symbols and patterns that glow a ghostly blue. Upon first glance, the Fang looks to be a regular wolf, albeit with some physical differences. The main specialty of the Fang of the Great Wolf only becomes evident when the wolf begins hunting. As it howls into the sky, its haunting cry piercing the surrounding silence, its runes begin to grow brighter than ever before. Various duplicates of the wolf begin to appear, seemingly manifesting from nothing but wind and snow. The beast’s howl has a secondary effect, filling whatever hears it with incomprehensible levels of mortal dread, forcing them into a panic. The wolves instinctually give chase, bringing the prey to its knees and dragging it off into the storm to be devoured.

resist.note: from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine

trait.name: Heated Body
entries: A creature that touches the magmadile or hits it with a melee attack while within 5 feet of it takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage.

trait.name: Earthen Crawl
entries: The magmadile can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. Unless the magmadile chooses otherwise, it doesn't disturb the material it moves through. If it has a creature {@condition grappled}, it can't choose not to disturb the material.

trait.name: Molten Dive
entries: The magmadile can only use its swim speed within lava, as it's too hot and dense to swim through water. When in water, molten magma excretes from the cracks in its rocky hide, hardening into stone. The magmadile creates a platform of obsidian within a radius of 10 feet, centered on itself. The magmadile can burrow through this obsidian if it has enough depth.

trait.name: Hold Breath
entries: The magmadile can hold its breath for 30 minutes.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. {@h}17 ({@damage 2d12 + 4}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) fire damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the magmadile can't bite another target or use its lava plume.

action.name: Lava Plume {@recharge 5}
entries: The magmadile expectorates a flowing gout of scorching magma in a 30-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. On a failure, the target takes 18 ({@damage 4d8}) bludgeoning damage and 18 ({@damage 4d8}) fire damage, and is pushed 30 feet away from the magmadile and knocked {@condition prone}. On a successful save the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed or knocked {@condition prone}.

The lava remains active on the ground where it lands, spreading an additional 5 feet from where it originates. It immolates unattended flammable objects and melts others. Any creature that starts its turn in the lava takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage. The lava remains active for {@dice 1d4} rounds before solidifying, grappling any creature trapped within it upon a failed {@dc 14} Dexterity saving throw. Any creature {@condition grappled} by the lava can escape with a successful {@dc 16} Strength saving throw.

{@italic Within the molten pools of boiling lava scattering the material plane, a massive beast lurks. With its molten, rock-like hide, a magmadile resembles a large chunk of igneous rock floating within the magma. This can prove to be a fatal mistake for many, as a magmadile is instead a massive reptilian predator that burns hotter than the lava it inhabits.}

{@bold Internal Flame.} A magmadile’s main food source is firenewts, attracted to the internal heat they possess. As a result, these reptiles adapted to survive within the harsh volcanic areas in which they inhabit in order to better hunt their preferred prey. As a result of preying on firenewts, magmadiles have consumed their special alchemical mixture enough times to truly incorporate it within their bodies, allowing them to withstand impossible temperatures and vomit boiling magma. \u000b     A miniature volcano that sprouts from their back erupts whenever they exhale lava, solidifying and hardening the magmadile’s rock-like scales. As a result of these scales, a magmadile can weigh up to 2 tons. As magmadiles are too dense and heavy to swim, they excrete magma from the cracks in their scales to solidify and create land. As a result, magmadiles can wreak havoc on wetlands and large bodies of water, transforming miles of water into dry land in just a matter of hours.

{@bold Underground Hunters.} While magmadiles are commonly seen carelessly drifting down flowing rivers of lava, this is one of the few times they can ever be seen. Magmadiles tunnel through the earth as they hunt, utilizing their intense, scorching magma to rapidly melt and recreate earth and stone, propelling themselves through the ground with their powerful tails. Similarly to bulettes, magmadiles attack from below, sensing the vibrations through the soil and rock from the unaware creatures above the surface. However, unlike the bulette, magmadiles are primarily ambush predators, leaving the earth around them undisturbed as they tunnel.

Magmadiles hunt similarly to their semi-aquatic cousins, waiting just under the surface of the earth to catch potential prey off-guard. They often follow just inches below whatever they intend to devour, attempting to gauge its size and strength through the vibrations it gives off as it walks. When the prey animal stops, the magmadile will burst from the ground, grasping the unsuspecting creature in its scorching jaws before dragging it below the soil to be devoured, leaving the surface completely undisturbed.

spellcasting.name: Innate Spellcasting
headerEntries: The shrieker's innate spellcasting ability is Constitution (spell save {@dc 16}, +8 to hit with spell attacks). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:

trait.name: Echolocation
entries: The shrieker can't use its blindsight while {@condition deafened}.

trait.name: Mimicry
entries: The shrieker can mimic any sounds it has heard, including voices. A creature that hears the sounds can tell they are imitations with a successful {@dc 15} Wisdom (Insight) check.

trait.name: Passing Bite
entries: If the shrieker moves at least 20 feet straight toward a target, it has advantage on its next attack roll against that target.

trait.name: Keen Hearing
entries: The shrieker has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shrieker makes a bite attack and a kicking claw attack.

action.name: Serrated Beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 3d6 + 4}) slashing damage. The target must succeed on a {@dc 14} Constitution saving throw or take 7 ({@damage 2d6}) slashing damage at the beginning of its next turn.

action.name: Kicking Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}11 ({@damage 1d12 + 4}) slashing damage.

action.name: Infrasound (1/Short Rest)
entries: The shrieker emits a low humming sound, causing its prey to hallucinate vividly. Any creature within 30 feet of the shrieker must succeed on a {@dc 16} Wisdom saving throw or begin seeing illusionary duplicates of the shrieker. The shrieker can control each duplicate individually although the illusionary duplicates can deal no damage nor can be damaged. Any afflicted creatures can repeat the save at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success. If a creature succeeds on its saving throw, it is immune to the shrieker's infrasound for 24 hours.

{@italic In the dense forests of the world, many dangerous creatures reside within. Bears, mammoths, tigers, wolves, the forest is a terrifying place that invokes a primal sense of fear so great that only the bravest few dare to venture inside. Shriekers utilizes this crippling fear to their advantage, preying on the frightened and isolated, feeding into their paranoia before finally striking while the creature is paralyzed with terror. }

{@bold Aberrant Predators.} While shriekers appear to be avian in appearance, these creatures have an alien anatomy that is more similar to an arthropod than any vertebrate. They rely on what can only be considered biological machinery to function, as their physiology is extremely complex and borderline unnatural. As a result, these creatures are capable of abilities that appear to be supernatural. Shriekers have two specialized chitinous organs extending from their backs that can emit a cloud of a nontoxic bleaching compound that absorbs direct sunlight, blackening the area around it. This compound spreads through the air like ink in water, blotting out any light in the area. Shriekers use this compound to trap terrified prey in a cloud of darkness, toying with them before ultimately delivering the killing blow with their unusually shaped beaks. These beaks are quite peculiar, consisting of a powerful, armored upper jaw and a much narrower lower jaw that splits into two serrated mandibles when opened fully. It is unknown what the purpose of this adaptation is.

{@bold Forest Dwellers.} Shriekers reside in dense temperate rainforests, claiming massive territories of thick forestland. They prefer areas where the canopy blots out sunlight, darkening the forest floor in a permanent shade of gray. They specialize in preying on skittish creatures, tormenting prey with their multiple adaptations before pouncing on them when they are at their most vulnerable. They prefer to ambush their prey, as they are quite cowardly in a one-on-one fight. By no means does this make them incapable of defending themselves, however, as they are capable of quickly turning the tables on would-be predators when cornered, utilizing their darkening compound to devastating effect. Shriekers are primarily solitary, but occasionally hunt in groups of two or three, although these hunting groups are extremely uncooperative and often form temporarily in order to take down larger prey.

{@bold Sound-Oriented.} Shriekers are known for their incredible mastery of sound, utilizing it for a number of various uses. Shriekers can map the surrounding environment entirely through echolocation, achieving this by opening a flap on the base of their skull, which contains an inner organ that acts similarly to an extremely sensitive eardrum. This enables them to pick up the slightest soundwaves with ease, allowing them to pinpoint the exact location of any sound in the surrounding area. They can produce powerful bursts of ear-piercing noise, shrieking loud enough to deal damage to their surroundings. Perhaps most peculiar, however, is their extended use of infrasound. By emitting inaudibly low frequencies, they can cause extreme paranoia and panic in most organisms, allowing them to trigger an ambush easily. Additionally, they can cause blindness in some creatures and deafen others simply by tampering with chemicals in the victim’s brain. They often provoke hallucinations in their prey, causing affected creatures to see illusionary duplicates of the shrieker that allow it to guide and herd the prey deeper into its hunting grounds.

trait.name: Limited Amphibiousness
entries: The luminous eel can breathe air and water, but it needs to be submerged at least once every six hours to avoid suffocating.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the luminous eel has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight.

trait.name: Static Shock
entries: The luminous eel's body generates a potent static charge. A creature that touches or makes a successful melee attack against the eel takes 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage.

trait.name: Lure
entries: While hidden or obscured by darkness, the luminous eel can use the lure on its head to create a series of mesmerizing flashes of light. Any creature that can see the lure must make make a {@dc 13} Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition charmed} for 1 minutes by the eel or until the eel harms the creature. While {@condition charmed} in this way, the creature may only use its turn to move towards the lure.

trait.name: Illumination
entries: As a bonus action, the luminous eel sheds bright light in a 10-foot radius and dim light in an additional 10 ft. This effect persists until the eel ends it with a bonus action.

trait.name: Abyssal Camouflage
entries: The luminous eel has advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks made to hide in the dark.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The luminous eel makes two attacks; one with its bite and one with its tail slap.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}16 ({@damage 3d6 + 6}) piercing damage plus 5 ({@damage 1d10}) lightning damage, and the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or become {@condition paralyzed} for {@dice 1d4} rounds. The target can repeat the save on the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If the target is immune to lightning damage, it can't be {@condition paralyzed}.

action.name: Tail
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 15 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d6 + 6}) bludgeoning damage plus 3 ({@damage 1d6}) lightning damage and the target is pushed up to 10 feet away.

action.name: Flash {@recharge}
entries: The luminous eel flashes its bio-luminescent organs in a blinding display of light in a 30-foot radius. Each creature in the area must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the end of their next turn.

{@italic In the darkest abyssal depths of the sea, a lone, dancing light bobs in the blackness of the void. A lost dolphin, separated from its pod, approaches the light, charmed by its rhythmic movements. Enchanted by the dancing orb, it doesn’t notice as several patches of eerie blue illuminate a massive creature poised directly behind the light. As crackling electricity dances around the bio-luminescent beast, the dolphin is too late to escape as the lure is extinguished and a massive pair of jaws come lunging toward it from the darkness.}

{@bold Darkness Dwellers.} The abyssal-dwelling luminous eel is a massive beast, reaching lengths of 20 feet on average. Most of their lives are spent in the darkest depths of the ocean or in lightless sea caves, hunting anything it perceives to be edible. The eels only venture to the surface twice in their lifetimes, and exclusively during violent oceanic storms. The first journey occurs just after an individual reaches sexual maturity, leading the eels to flock to beaches and coastal habitats in order to breed. It is generally during this event that most attacks occur, as large, dominant males will attack anything that it senses to be a threat. Rival males will strike each other with their long, lashing tails, attempting to knock each other into submission. The victor of these battles will then put on a glorious bio-luminescent display in order to attract a mate. After mating, females will devour the males and remain on the coast before returning to the sea at the storm’s conclusion. Roughly seven to eight months later, the females, having grown even larger than the males at this point in their lives, will return to the beach at which they mated, travelling inland to lay eggs and hunt. They prefer to find places with high levels of static electricity to lay their clutch. After laying, the eels will remain around the coast until the storm ends, at which point they will venture back into the ocean to die. The newborn eels will hatch roughly a week later, returning to the sea in order to begin the cycle anew.

{@bold Electrogenic Hunters:} Luminous eels prefer to hunt similarly to anglerfish, enthralling potential prey with their dancing lure before striking when the target is effectively harmless. The bio-luminescent organs lining their bodies also act similarly to the specialized organs of an electric eel (Main organ, Sachs’ organ, and Hunter’s organ), allowing for electroreception, electrolocation, and, to a much more intense extent, electrocution. The eel channels static electricity via the sodium-potassium exchanger, which maintains a voltage imbalance between the inside of the eel’s cells and their surroundings. The exchanger is said to be “electrogenic” because it removes three sodium ions for every two ions of potassium it allows in. The eel’s bio-luminescent organs have the highest concentration of electrolyte exchangers, with an uneven distribution throughout the rest of its body. Luminous eels have several thousand of these exchanger cells stacked atop one another, capable of a discharge of over 900 V.

{@bold Rogue Males:} When most members of the species are breeding, a select few male individuals will travel too far in search of a mate, eventually getting trapped inland as the storm passes. These rogue males aren’t slaughtered by their mates and are thus left to grow and hunt as they please. These eels lair in coastal caves with various pools of water readily available to allow for easy access to the sea. Transitioning to a more terrestrial lifestyle, these rogue males claim large territories, ranging anywhere from 20 to 40 square miles.
